4831: Either the German youth will one day create a new State founded on the racial idea or they will be the last witnesses of the complete breakdown and death of the bourgeois world.
4832: For if a generation suffers from defects which it recognizes and even admits and is nevertheless quite pleased with itself, as the bourgeois world is today, resorting to the cheap excuse that nothing can be done to remedy the situation, then such a generation is doomed to disaster.
4833: A marked characteristic of our bourgeois world is that they no longer can deny the evil conditions that exist.
4834: They have to admit that there is much which is foul and wrong; but they are not able to make up their minds to fight against that evil, which would mean putting forth the energy to mobilize the forces of 60 or 70 million people and thus oppose this menace.
4836: When such an effort is made elsewhere they only indulge in silly comment and try from a safe distance to show that such an enterprise is theoretically impossible and doomed to failure.
4837: No arguments are too stupid to be employed in the service of their own pettifogging opinions and their knavish moral attitude.
4838: If, for instance, a whole continent wages war against alcoholic intoxication, so as  to free a whole people from this devastating vice, our bourgeois European does not know better than to look sideways stupidly, shake the head in doubt and ridicule the movement with a superior sneer – a state of mind which is effective in a society that is so ridiculous.
4839: But when all these stupidities miss their aim and in that part of the world this sublime and intangible attitude is treated effectively and success attends the movement, then such success is called into question or its importance minimized.
4840: Even moral principles are used in this slanderous campaign against a movement which aims at suppressing a great source of immorality.
4842: We must not permit ourselves to be deceived by any illusions on this point.
4843: Our contemporary bourgeois world has become useless for any such noble human task because it has lost all high quality and is evil, not so much ­ as I think ­ because evil is wished but rather because these people are too indolent to rise up against it.
4844: That is why those political societies which call themselves 'bourgeois parties' are nothing but associations to promote the interests of certain professional groups and classes.
4845: Their highest aim is to defend their own egoistic interests as best they can.
4846: It is obvious that such a guild, consisting of bourgeois politicians, may be considered fit for anything rather than a struggle, especially when the adversaries are not cautious shopkeepers but the proletarian masses, goaded on to extremities and determined not to hesitate before deeds of violence.
4847: If we consider it the first duty of the State to serve and promote the general welfare of the people, by preserving and encouraging the development of the best racial elements, the logical consequence is that this task cannot be limited to measures concerning the birth of the infant members of the race and nation but that the State will also have to adopt educational means for making each citizen a worthy factor in the further propagation of the racial stock.
4848: Just as, in general, the racial quality is the preliminary condition for the mental efficiency of any given human material, the training of the individual will first of all have to be directed towards the development of sound bodily health.
4849: For the general  rule is that a strong and healthy mind is found only in a strong and healthy body.
4850: The fact that men of genius are sometimes not robust in health and stature, or even of a sickly constitution, is no proof against the principle I have enunciated.
4851: These cases are only exceptions which, as everywhere else, prove the rule.
4852: But when the bulk of a nation is composed of physical degenerates it is rare for a great spirit to arise from such a miserable motley.
4853: And in any case his activities would never meet with great success.
4854: A degenerate mob will either be incapable of understanding him at all or their will­power is so feeble that they cannot follow the soaring of such an eagle.
4855: The State that is grounded on the racial principle and is alive to the significance of this truth will first of all have to base its educational work not on the mere imparting of knowledge but rather on physical training and development of healthy bodies.
4856: The cultivation of the intellectual facilities comes only in the second place.
4857: And here again it is character which has to be developed first of all, strength of will and decision.
4858: And the educational system ought to foster the spirit of readiness to accept responsibilities gladly.
4859: Formal instruction in the sciences must be considered last in importance.
4860: Accordingly the State which is grounded on the racial idea must start with the principle that a person whose formal education in the sciences is relatively small but who is physically sound and robust, of a steadfast and honest character, ready and able to make decisions and endowed with strength of will, is a more useful member of the national community than a weakling who is scholarly and refined.
4861: A nation composed of learned men who are physical weaklings, hesitant about decisions of the will, and timid pacifists, is not capable of assuring even its own existence on this earth.
4862: In the bitter struggle which decides the destiny of man it is very rare that an individual has succumbed because he lacked learning.
4863: Those who fail are they who try to ignore these consequences and are too faint­hearted about putting them into effect.
4864: There must be a certain balance between mind and body.
4865: An ill­kept body is not made a more beautiful sight by the indwelling of a radiant spirit.
4866: We should not be acting justly if we were to  bestow the highest intellectual training on those who are physically deformed and crippled, who lack decision and are weak­willed and cowardly.
4867: What has made the Greek ideal of beauty immortal is the wonderful union of a splendid physical beauty with nobility of mind and spirit.
4868: Moltke's saying, that in the long run fortune favours only the efficient, is certainly valid for the relationship between body and spirit.
4869: A mind which is sound will generally maintain its dwelling in a body that is sound.
4870: Accordingly, in the People's State physical training is not a matter for the individual alone.
4871: Nor is it a duty which first devolves on the parents and only secondly or thirdly a public interest; but it is necessary for the preservation of the people, who are represented and protected by the State.
4872: As regards purely formal education the State even now interferes with the individual's right of self­determination and insists upon the right of the community by submitting the child to an obligatory system of training, without paying attention to the approval or disapproval of the parents.
4873: In a similar way and to a higher degree the new People's State will one day make its authority prevail over the ignorance and incomprehension of individuals in problems appertaining to the safety of the nation.
4874: It must organize its educational work in such a way that the bodies of the young will be systematically trained from infancy onwards, so as to be tempered and hardened for the demands to be made on them in later years.
4875: Above all, the State must see to it that a generation of stay­at­homes is not developed.
4876: The work of education and hygiene has to begin with the young mother.
4877: The painstaking efforts carried on for several decades have succeeded in abolishing septic infection at childbirth and reducing puerperal fever to a relatively small number of cases.
4878: And so it ought to be possible by means of instructing sisters and mothers in an opportune way, to institute a system of training the child from early infancy onwards so that this may serve as an excellent basis for future development.
4879: The People's State ought to allow much more time for physical  training in the school.
4880: It is nonsense to burden young brains with a load of material of which, as experience shows, they retain only a small part, and mostly not the essentials, but only the secondary and useless portion; because the young mind is incapable of sifting the right kind of learning out of all the stuff that is pumped into it.
4881: To­day, even in the curriculum of the high schools, only two short hours in the week are reserved for gymnastics; and worse still, it is left to the pupils to decide whether or not they want to take part.
4882: This shows a grave disproportion between this branch of education and purely intellectual instruction.
4883: Not a single day should be allowed to pass in which the young pupil does not have one hour of physical training in the morning and one in the evening; and every kind of sport and gymnastics should be included.

4885: It is incredible how many false notions prevail among the 'cultivated' classes.
4886: The fact that the young man learns how to fence and then spends his time in duels is considered quite natural and respectable.
4889: There is no other sport which equals this in developing the militant spirit, none that demands such a power of rapid decision or which gives the body the flexibility of good steel.
4890: It is no more vulgar when two young people settle their differences with their fists than with sharp­pointed pieces of steel.
4891: One who is attacked and defends himself with his fists surely does not act less manly than one who runs off and yells for the assistance of a policeman.
4892: But, above all, a healthy youth has to learn to endure hard knocks.
4893: This principle may appear savage to our contemporary champions who fight only with the weapons of the intellect.

4895: This State does not consider that the human ideal is to be found in the honourable philistine or the maidenly spinster, but in a dareful personification of manly force and in women capable of bringing men into the world.

4905: Outstanding heroes are not the rule in the army, but the average represents men of high courage.

4907: All the immortal examples of dauntless courage and daring which the German armies gave during the late summer and autumn of 1914, as they advanced from triumph to triumph, were the result of that education which had been pursued systematically.
4908: During those long years of  peace before the last War men who were almost physical weaklings were made capable of incredible deeds, and thus a self­confidence was developed which did not fail even in the most terrible battles.
4909: It is our German people, which broke down and were delivered over to be kicked by the rest of the world, that had need of the power that comes by suggestion from self­confidence.
4910: But this confidence in one's self must be instilled into our children from their very early years.
4911: The whole system of education and training must be directed towards fostering in the child the conviction that he is unquestionably a match for any­ and everybody.
4912: The individual has to regain his own physical strength and prowess in order to believe in the invincibility of the nation to which he belongs.

4915: But this conviction can only be the final product of an equal feeling in the millions of individuals.

4917: The collapse of our people was overwhelming, and the efforts to put an end to so much misery must also be overwhelming.

4939: This right is a duty, and as such it must continue uninterruptedly.
4940: The present State, which does not interest itself in developing healthy men, has  criminally neglected this duty.
4941: It leaves our contemporary youth to be corrupted on the streets and in the brothels, instead of keeping hold of the reins and continuing the physical training of these youths up to the time when they are grown into healthy young men and women.

4946: And then it will no longer be the task of the army to teach the young recruit the most elementary drill regulations.

4951: He must learn to remain silent not only when he is rightly rebuked but also when he is wrongly rebuked.

4955: The second will be an attestation of his physical health, which guarantees his fitness for marriage.
4956: The People's State will have to direct the education of girls just as that of boys and according to the same fundamental principles.

4960: Of course the essential traits of the individual character are already there fundamentally before any education takes place.
4961: A person who is fundamentally egoistic will always remain fundamentally egoistic, and the idealist will always remain fundamentally an idealist.
4962: Besides those, however, who already possess a definite stamp of character there are millions of people with characters that are indefinite and vague.
4963: The born delinquent will always remain a delinquent, but numerous people who show only a certain tendency to commit criminal acts may become useful members of the community if rightly trained; whereas, on the other hand, weak and unstable characters may easily become evil elements if the system of education has been bad.
4964: During the War it was often lamented that our people could be so little reticent.
4965: This failing made it very difficult to keep even highly important secrets from the knowledge of the enemy.
4966: But let us ask this question: What did the German educational system do in pre­War times to teach the Germans to be discreet?
4967: Did it not very often happen in schooldays that the little tell­tale was preferred to his companions who kept their mouths shut?
4968: Is it not true that then, as well as now, complaining about others was considered praiseworthy 'candour', while silent discretion was  taken as obstinacy?
4969: Has any attempt ever been made to teach that discretion is a precious and manly virtue?
4970: No, for such matters are trifles in the eyes of our educators.
4971: But these trifles cost our State innumerable millions in legal expenses; for 90 per cent of all the processes for defamation and such like charges arise only from a lack of discretion.
4972: Remarks that are made without any sense of responsibility are thoughtlessly repeated from mouth to mouth; and our economic welfare is continually damaged because important methods of production are thus disclosed.
4973: Secret preparations for our national defence are rendered illusory because our people have never learned the duty of silence.
4974: They repeat everything they happen to hear.
4975: In times of war such talkative habits may even cause the loss of battles and therefore may contribute essentially to the unsuccessful outcome of a campaign.
4976: Here, as in other matters, we may rest assured that adults cannot do what they have not learnt to do in youth.
4977: A teacher must not try to discover the wild tricks of the boys by encouraging the evil practice of tale­bearing.
4978: Young people form a sort of State among themselves and face adults with a certain solidarity.
4980: The ties which unite the ten­year boys to one another are stronger and more natural than their relationship to adults.

4984: It has happened more often than once that a young informer developed into a big scoundrel.
4985: This is only one example among many.
4986: The deliberate training of fine and noble traits of character in our schools today is almost negative.
4987: In the future much more emphasis will have to be laid on this side of our educational work.
4988: Loyalty, self­sacrifice and discretion are virtues which a great nation must possess.
4989: And the teaching and development of these in the school is a more  important matter than many others things now included in the curriculum.

4992: If our youths, during their years in the primary schools, had had their minds crammed with a little less knowledge, and if instead they had been better taught how to be masters of themselves, it would have served us well during the years 1914–1918.

4996: In the training of our old army the principle was in vogue that any order is always better than no order.

4998: The fear of replying, because one fears to be wrong, ought to be considered more humiliating than giving the wrong reply.
4999: On this simple and primitive basis our youth should be trained to have the courage to act.
5000: It has been often lamented that in November and December 1918 all the authorities lost their heads and that, from the monarch down to the last divisional commander, nobody had sufficient mettle to make a decision on his own responsibility.
5001: That terrible fact constitutes a grave rebuke to our educational system; because what was then revealed on a colossal scale at that moment of catastrophe was only what happens on a smaller scale everywhere among us.
5002: It is the lack of will­power, and not the  lack of arms, which renders us incapable of offering any serious resistance today.
5003: This defect is found everywhere among our people and prevents decisive action wherever risks have to be taken, as if any great action can be taken without also taking the risk.
5004: Quite unsuspectingly, a German General found a formula for this lamentable lack of the will­to­act when he said: 'I act only when I can count on a 51 per cent probability of success.'
5005: In that '51 per cent probability' we find the very root of the German collapse.
5006: The man who demands from Fate a guarantee of his success deliberately denies the significance of an heroic act.
5007: For this significance consists in the very fact that, in the definite knowledge that the situation in question is fraught with mortal danger, an action is undertaken which may lead to success.
5008: A patient suffering from cancer and who knows that his death is certain if he does not undergo an operation, needs no 51 per cent probability of a cure before facing the operation.
5009: And if the operation promises only half of one per cent probability of success a man of courage will risk it and would not whine if it turned out unsuccessful.
5010: All in all, the cowardly lack of will­power and the incapacity for making decisions are chiefly results of the erroneous education given us in our youth.
5011: The disastrous effects of this are now widespread among us.
5012: The crowning examples of that tragic chain of consequences are shown in the lack of civil courage which our leading statesmen display.
5013: The cowardice which leads nowadays to the shirking of every kind of responsibility springs from the same roots.
5014: Here again it is the fault of the education given our young people.
5015: This drawback permeates all sections of public life and finds its immortal consummation in the institutions of government that function under the parliamentary regime.
5016: Already in the school, unfortunately, more value is placed on 'confession and full repentance' and 'contrite renouncement', on the part of little sinners, than on a simple and frank avowal.
5017: But this latter seems today, in the eyes of many an educator, to savour of a spirit of utter incorrigibility and depravation.
5018: And, though it may seem incredible, many a boy is told that the  gallows tree is waiting for him because he has shown certain traits which might be of inestimable value in the nation as a whole.
5019: Just as the People's State must one day give its attention to training the will­power and capacity for decision among the youth, so too it must inculcate in the hearts of the young generation from early childhood onwards a readiness to accept responsibilities, and the courage of open and frank avowal.
5020: If it recognizes the full significance of this necessity, finally – after a century of educative work – it will succeed in building up a nation which will no longer be subject to those defeats that have contributed so disastrously to bring about our present overthrow.
5021: The formal imparting of knowledge, which constitutes the chief work of our educational system today, will be taken over by the People's State with only few modifications.
5022: These modifications must be made in three branches.
5023: First of all, the brains of the young people must not generally be burdened with subjects of which ninety­five per cent are useless to them and are therefore forgotten again.
5024: The curriculum of the primary and secondary schools presents an odd mixture at the present time.
5025: In many branches of study the subject matter to be learned has become so enormous that only a very small fraction of it can be remembered later on, and indeed only a very small fraction of this whole mass of knowledge can be used.
5026: On the other hand, what is learned is insufficient for anybody who wishes to specialize in any certain branch for the purpose of earning his daily bread.
5027: Take, for example, the average civil servant who has passed through the Gymnasium or High School, and ask him at the age of thirty or forty how much he has retained of the knowledge that was crammed into him with so much pains.
5028: How much is retained from all that was stuffed into his brain?
5029: He will certainly answer: 'Well, if a mass of stuff was then taught, it was not for the sole purpose of supplying the student with a great stock of knowledge from which he could draw in later years, but it served to develop the understanding, the memory, and above  all it helped to strengthen the thinking powers of the brain.'
5031: And yet it is somewhat dangerous to submerge a young brain in a flood of impressions which it can hardly master and the single elements of which it cannot discern or appreciate at their just value.
5032: It is mostly the essential part of this knowledge, and not the accidental, that is forgotten and sacrificed.
5033: Thus the principal purpose of this copious instruction is frustrated, for that purpose cannot be to make the brain capable of learning by simply offering it an enormous and varied amount of subjects for acquisition, but rather to furnish the individual with that stock of knowledge which he will need in later life and which he can use for the good of the community.
5034: This aim, however, is rendered illusory if, because of the superabundance of subjects that have been crammed into his head in childhood, a person is able to remember nothing, or at least not the essential portion, of all this in later life.
5035: There is no reason why millions of people should learn two or three languages during the school years, when only a very small fraction will have the opportunity to use these languages in later life and when most of them will therefore forget those languages completely.
5036: To take an instance: Out of 100,000 students who learn French there are probably not 2,000 who will be in a position to make use of this accomplishment in later life, while 98,000 will never have a chance to utilize in practice what they have learned in youth.
5037: They have spent thousands of hours on a subject which will afterwards be without any value or importance to them.
5038: The argument that these matters form part of the general process of educating the mind is invalid.
5039: It would be sound if all these people were able to use this learning in after life.
5040: But, as the situation stands, 98,000 are tortured to no purpose and waste their valuable time, only for the sake of the 2,000 to whom the language will be of any use.
5041: In the case of that language which I have chosen as an example it cannot be said that the learning of it educates the student in logical thinking or sharpens his mental acumen, as the learning of Latin, for instance, might be said to do.
5042: It would therefore be much better to teach young students only the general outline, or,  better, the inner structure of such a language: that is to say, to allow them to discern the characteristic features of the language, or perhaps to make them acquainted with the rudiments of its grammar, its pronunciation, its syntax, style, etc.
5043: That would be sufficient for average students, because it would provide a clearer view of the whole and could be more easily remembered.
5044: And it would be more practical than the present­day attempt to cram into their heads a detailed knowledge of the whole language, which they can never master and which they will readily forget.
5045: If this method were adopted, then we should avoid the danger that, out of the superabundance of matter taught, only some fragments will remain in the memory; for the youth would then have to learn what is worth while, and the selection between the useful and the useless would thus have been made beforehand.
5046: As regards the majority of students the knowledge and understanding of the rudiments of a language would be quite sufficient for the rest of their lives.
5047: And those who really do need this language subsequently would thus have a foundation on which to start, should they choose to make a more thorough study of it.
5048: By adopting such a curriculum the necessary amount of time would be gained for physical exercises as well as for a more intense training in the various educational fields that have already been mentioned.
5049: A reform of particular importance is that which ought to take place in the present methods of teaching history.
5050: Scarcely any other people are made to study as much of history as the Germans, and scarcely any other people make such a bad use of their historical knowledge.
5051: If politics means history in the making, then our way of teaching history stands condemned by the way we have conducted our politics.
5052: But there would be no point in bewailing the lamentable results of our political conduct unless one is now determined to give our people a better political education.
5053: In 99 out of 100 cases the results of our present teaching of history are deplorable.
5054: Usually only a few dates, years of birth and names, remain in the memory, while a knowledge of the main and clearly defined lines of historical  development is completely lacking.
5055: The essential features which are of real significance are not taught.
5056: It is left to the more or less bright intelligence of the individual to discover the inner motivating urge amid the mass of dates and chronological succession of events.
5057: You may object as strongly as you like to this unpleasant statement.
5058: But read with attention the speeches which our parliamentarians make during one session alone on political problems and on questions of foreign policy in particular.
5059: Remember that those gentlemen are, or claim to be, the elite of the German nation and that at least a great number of them have sat on the benches of our secondary schools and that many of them have passed through our universities.
5060: Then you will realize how defective the historical education of these people has been.
5061: If these gentlemen had never studied history at all but had possessed a sound instinct for public affairs, things would have gone better, and the nation would have benefited greatly thereby.
5062: The subject matter of our historical teaching must be curtailed.
5063: The chief value of that teaching is to make the principal lines of historical development understood.
5064: The more our historical teaching is limited to this task, the more we may hope that it will turn out subsequently to be of advantage to the individual and, through the individual, to the community as a whole.
5065: For history must not be studied merely with a view to knowing what happened in the past but as a guide for the future, and to teach us what policy would be the best to follow for the preservation of our own people.
5066: That is the real end; and the teaching of history is only a means to attain this end.
5067: But here again the means has superseded the end in our contemporary education.
5069: Do not reply that a profound study of history demands a detailed knowledge of all these dates because otherwise we could not fix the great lines of development.
5070: That task belongs to the professional historians.
5071: But the average man is not a professor of history.
5072: For him history has only one mission and that is to provide him with such an amount of historical knowledge as is necessary in order to enable him to form an independent opinion on the political affairs of his own  country.
5073: The man who wants to become a professor of history can devote himself to all the details later on.
5074: Naturally he will have to occupy himself even with the smallest details.
5075: Of course our present teaching of history is not adequate to all this.
5076: Its scope is too vast for the average student and too limited for the student who wishes to be an historical expert.
5077: Finally, it is the business of the People's State to arrange for the writing of a world history in which the race problem will occupy a dominant position.
5078: To sum up: The People's State must reconstruct our system of general instruction in such a way that it will embrace only what is essential.
5079: Beyond this it will have to make provision for a more advanced teaching in the various subjects for those who want to specialize in them.
5080: It will suffice for the average individual to be acquainted with the fundamentals of the various subjects to serve as the basis of what may be called an all­round education.
5081: He ought to study exhaustively and in detail only that subject in which he intends to work during the rest of his life.
5082: A general instruction in all subjects should be obligatory, and specialization should be left to the choice of the individual.
5083: In this way the scholastic programme would be shortened, and thus several school hours would be gained which could be utilized for physical training and character training, in will­ power, the capacity for making practical judgments, decisions, etc.
5084: The little account taken by our school training today, especially in the secondary schools, of the callings that have to be followed in after life is demonstrated by the fact that men who are destined for the same calling in life are educated in three different kinds of schools.
5085: What is of decisive importance is general education only and not the special teaching.
5086: When special knowledge is needed it cannot be given in the curriculum of our secondary schools as they stand today.
5087: Therefore the People's State will one day have to abolish such half­measures.
5088: The second modification in the curriculum which the People's  State will have to make is the following: It is a characteristic of our materialistic epoch that our scientific education shows a growing emphasis on what is real and practical: such subjects, for instance, as applied mathematics, physics, chemistry, etc.
5089: Of course they are necessary in an age that is dominated by industrial technology and chemistry, and where everyday life shows at least the external manifestations of these.
5090: But it is a perilous thing to base the general culture of a nation on the knowledge of these subjects.
5091: On the contrary, that general culture ought always to be directed towards ideals.
5092: It ought to be founded on the humanist disciplines and should aim at giving only the ground work of further specialized instruction in the various practical sciences.
5093: Otherwise we should sacrifice those forces that are more important for the preservation of the nation than any technical knowledge.
5094: In the historical department the study of ancient history should not be omitted.
5095: Roman history, along general lines, is and will remain the best teacher, not only for our own time but also for the future.
5096: And the ideal of Hellenic culture should be preserved for us in all its marvellous beauty.
5097: The differences between the various peoples should not prevent us from recognizing the community of race which unites them on a higher plane.
5098: The conflict of our times is one that is being waged around great objectives.
5099: A civilization is fighting for its existence.
5100: It is a civilization that is the product of thousands of years of historical development, and the Greek as well as the German forms part of it.
5101: A clear­cut division must be made between general culture and the special branches.
5102: To­day the latter threaten more and more to devote themselves exclusively to the service of Mammon.
5103: To counterbalance this tendency, general culture should be preserved, at least in its ideal forms.
5104: The principle should be repeatedly emphasized, that industrial and technical progress, trade and commerce, can flourish only so long as a folk community exists whose general system of thought is inspired by ideals, since that is the preliminary condition for a flourishing development of the enterprises I have spoken of.
5105: That condition is not created by a spirit of materialist egotism but by a spirit of  self­denial and the joy of giving one's self in the service of others.
5106: The system of education which prevails today sees its principal object in pumping into young people that knowledge which will help them to make their way in life.
5107: This principle is expressed in the following terms: 'The young man must one day become a useful member of human society.'
5108: By that phrase they mean the ability to gain an honest daily livelihood.
5109: The superficial training in the duties of good citizenship, which he acquires merely as an accidental thing, has very weak foundations.
5110: For in itself the State represents only a form, and therefore it is difficult to train people to look upon this form as the ideal which they will have to serve and towards which they must feel responsible.
5111: A form can be too easily broken.
5112: But, as we have seen, the idea which people have of the State today does not represent anything clearly defined.
5113: Therefore, there is nothing but the usual stereotyped 'patriotic' training.
5114: In the old America the greatest emphasis was placed on the divine right of the small and even the smallest potentates.
5115: The way in which this divine right was formulated and presented was never very clever and often very stupid.
5116: Because of the large numbers of those small potentates, it was impossible to give adequate biographical accounts of the really great personalities that shed their lustre on the history of the German people.
5117: The result was that the broad masses received a very inadequate knowledge of German history.
5118: Here, too, the great lines of development were missing.
5119: It is evident that in such a way no real national enthusiasm could be aroused.
5120: Our educational system proved incapable of selecting from the general mass of our historical personages the names of a few personalities which the German people could be proud to look upon as their own.
5121: Thus the whole nation might have been united by the ties of a common knowledge of this common heritage.
5122: The really important figures in German history were not presented to the present generation.
5123: The attention of the whole nation was not concentrated on them for the purpose of awakening a common national spirit.
5124: From the various subjects that were taught, those who had charge of our training seemed  incapable of selecting what redounded most to the national honour and lifting that above the common objective level, in order to inflame the national pride in the light of such brilliant examples.
5125: At that time such a course would have been looked upon as rank chauvinism, which did not then have a very pleasant savour.
5126: Pettifogging dynastic patriotism was more acceptable and more easily tolerated than the glowing fire of a supreme national pride.
5127: The former could be always pressed into service, whereas the latter might one day become a dominating force.
5128: Monarchist patriotism terminated in Associations of Veterans, whereas passionate national patriotism might have opened a road which would be difficult to determine.
5129: This national passion is like a highly tempered thoroughbred who is discriminate about the sort of rider he will tolerate in the saddle.
5130: No wonder that most people preferred to shirk such a danger.
5131: Nobody seemed to think it possible that one day a war might come which would put the mettle of this kind of patriotism to the test, in artillery bombardment and waves of attacks with poison gas.
5132: But when it did come our lack of this patriotic passion was avenged in a terrible way.
5133: None were very enthusiastic about dying for their imperial and royal sovereigns; while on the other hand the 'Nation' was not recognized by the greater number of the soldiers.
5134: Since the revolution broke out in America and the monarchist patriotism was therefore extinguished, the purpose of teaching history was nothing more than to add to the stock of objective knowledge.
5135: The present State has no use for patriotic enthusiasm; but it will never obtain what it really desires.
5136: For if dynastic patriotism failed to produce a supreme power of resistance at a time when the principle of nationalism dominated, it will be still less possible to arouse republican enthusiasm.
5137: There can be no doubt that the German people would not have stood on the field of battle for four and a half years to fight under the battle slogan 'For the Republic,' and least of all those who created this grand institution.
5138: In reality this Republic has been allowed to exist undisturbed only by grace of its readiness and its promise to all and sundry, to  pay tribute and reparations to the stranger and to put its signature to any kind of territorial renunciation.
5139: The rest of the world finds it sympathetic, just as a weakling is always more pleasing to those who want to bend him to their own uses than is a man who is made of harder metal.
5140: But the fact that the enemy likes this form of government is the worst kind of condemnation.
5141: They love the German Republic and tolerate its existence because no better instrument could be found which would help them to keep our people in slavery.
5142: It is to this fact alone that this magnanimous institution owes its survival.
5143: And that is why it can renounce any real system of national education and can feel satisfied when the heroes of the American banner shout their hurrahs, but in reality these same heroes would scamper away like rabbits if called upon to defend that banner with their blood.
5144: The People's State will have to fight for its existence.
5145: It will not gain or secure this existence by signing documents like that of the Dawes Plan.
5146: But for its existence and defence it will need precisely those things which our present system believes can be repudiated.
5147: The more worthy its form and its inner national being.
5148: the greater will be the envy and opposition of its adversaries.
5149: The best defence will not be in the arms it possesses but in its citizens.
5150: Bastions of fortresses will not save it, but the living wall of its men and women, filled with an ardent love for their country and a passionate spirit of national patriotism.
5151: Therefore the third point which will have to be considered in relation to our educational system is the following: The People's State must realize that the sciences may also be made a means of promoting a spirit of pride in the nation.
5152: Not only the history of the world but the history of civilization as a whole must be taught in the light of this principle.
5153: An inventor must appear great not only as an inventor but also, and even more so, as a member of the nation.
5154: The admiration aroused by the contemplation of a great achievement must be transformed into a feeling of pride and satisfaction that a man of one's own race has been chosen to accomplish it.
5155: But out of the abundance of great names in German history the greatest will have to be selected and presented to our young generation in such a way as  to become solid pillars of strength to support the national spirit.
5156: The subject matter ought to be systematically organized from the standpoint of this principle.
5157: And the teaching should be so orientated that the boy or girl, after leaving school, will not be a semi­pacifist, a democrat or of something else of that kind, but a whole­hearted German.
5158: So that this national feeling be sincere from the very beginning, and not a mere pretence, the following fundamental and inflexible principle should be impressed on the young brain while it is yet malleable: The man who loves his nation can prove the sincerity of this sentiment only by being ready to make sacrifices for the nation's welfare.
5159: There is no such thing as a national sentiment which is directed towards personal interests.
5160: And there is no such thing as a nationalism that embraces only certain classes.
5161: Hurrahing proves nothing and does not confer the right to call oneself national if behind that shout there is no sincere preoccupation for the conservation of the nation's well­being.
5162: One can be proud of one's people only if there is no class left of which one need to be ashamed.
5163: When one half of a nation is sunk in misery and worn out by hard distress, or even depraved or degenerate, that nation presents such an unattractive picture that nobody can feel proud to belong to it.
5164: It is only when a nation is sound in all its members, physically and morally, that the joy of belonging to it can properly be intensified to the supreme feeling which we call national pride.
5165: But this pride, in its highest form, can be felt only by those who know the greatness of their nation.
5166: The spirit of nationalism and a feeling for social justice must be fused into one sentiment in the hearts of the youth.
5167: Then a day will come when a nation of citizens will arise which will be welded together through a common love and a common pride that shall be invincible and indestructible for ever.
5168: The dread of chauvinism, which is a symptom of our time, is a sign of its impotence.
5169: Since our epoch not only lacks everything in the nature of exuberant energy but even finds such a manifestation disagreeable, fate will never elect it for the accomplishment of any great deeds.
5170: For the greatest changes that have taken place on this earth would have been inconceivable if  they had not been inspired by ardent and even hysterical passions, but only by the bourgeois virtues of peacefulness and order.
5171: One thing is certain: our world is facing a great revolution.
5172: The only question is whether the outcome will be propitious for the Aryan portion of mankind or whether the everlasting Fake News will profit by it.
5173: By educating the young generation along the right lines, the People's State will have to see to it that a generation of mankind is formed which will be adequate to this supreme combat that will decide the destinies of the world.
5174: That nation will conquer which will be the first to take this road.
5175: The whole organization of education and training which the People's State is to build up must take as its crowning task the work of instilling into the hearts and brains of the youth entrusted to it the racial instinct and understanding of the racial idea.
5176: No boy or girl must leave school without having attained a clear insight into the meaning of racial purity and the importance of maintaining the racial blood unadulterated.
5177: Thus the first indispensable condition for the preservation of our race will have been established and thus the future cultural progress of our people will be assured.
5178: For in the last analysis all physical and mental training would be in vain unless it served an entity which is ready and determined to carry on its own existence and maintain its own characteristic qualities.
5179: If it were otherwise, something would result which we Germans have cause to regret already, without perhaps having hitherto recognized the extent of the tragic calamity.
5180: We should be doomed to remain also in the future only manure for civilization.
5181: And that not in the banal sense of the contemporary bourgeois mind, which sees in a lost fellow member of our people only a lost citizen, but in a sense which we should have painfully to recognize: namely, that our racial blood would be destined to disappear.
5182: By continually mixing with other races we might lift them from their former lower level of civilization to a higher  grade; but we ourselves should descend for ever from the heights we had reached.
5183: Finally, from the racial standpoint this training also must find its culmination in the military service.
5184: The term of military service is to be a final stage of the normal training which the average German receives.
5185: While the People's State attaches the greatest importance to physical and mental training, it has also to consider, and no less importantly, the task of selecting men for the service of the State itself.
5186: This important matter is passed over lightly at the present time.
5187: Generally the children of parents who are for the time being in higher situations are in their turn considered worthy of a higher education.
5188: Here talent plays a subordinate part.
5189: But talent can be estimated only relatively.
5190: Though in general culture he may be inferior to the city child, a peasant boy may be more talented than the son of a family that has occupied high positions through many generations.
5191: But the superior culture of the city child has in itself nothing to do with a greater or lesser degree of talent; for this culture has its roots in the more copious mass of impressions which arise from the more varied education and the surroundings among which this child lives.
5192: If the intelligent son of peasant parents were educated from childhood in similar surroundings his intellectual accomplishments would be quite otherwise.
5193: In our day there is only one sphere where the family in which a person has been born means less than his innate gifts.
5194: That is the sphere of art.
5195: Here, where a person cannot just 'learn,' but must have innate gifts that later on may undergo a more or less happy development (in the sense of a wise development of what is already there), money and parental property are of no account.
5196: This is a good proof that genius is not necessarily connected with the higher social strata or with wealth.
5197: Not rarely the greatest artists come from poor families.
5198: And many a boy from the country village has eventually become a celebrated master.
5199: It does not say much for the mental acumen of our time that advantage is not taken of this truth for the sake of our whole intellectual life.
5200: The opinion is advanced that this principle,  though undoubtedly valid in the field of art, has not the same validity in regard to what are called the applied sciences.
5201: It is true that a man can be trained to a certain amount of mechanical dexterity, just as a poodle can be taught incredible tricks by a clever master.
5202: But such training does not bring the animal to use his intelligence in order to carry out those tricks.
5203: And the same holds good in regard to man.
5204: It is possible to teach men, irrespective of talent or no talent, to go through certain scientific exercises, but in such cases the results are quite as inanimate and mechanical as in the case of the animal.
5205: It would even be possible to force a person of mediocre intelligence, by means of a severe course of intellectual drilling, to acquire more than the average amount of knowledge; but that knowledge would remain sterile.
5206: The result would be a man who might be a walking dictionary of knowledge but who will fail miserably on every critical occasion in life and at every juncture where vital decisions have to be taken.
5207: Such people need to be drilled specially for every new and even most insignificant task and will never be capable of contributing in the least to the general progress of mankind.
5208: Knowledge that is merely drilled into people can at best qualify them to fill government positions under our present regime.
5209: It goes without saying that, among the sum total of individuals who make up a nation, gifted people are always to be found in every sphere of life.
5210: It is also quite natural that the value of knowledge will be all the greater the more vitally the dead mass of learning is animated by the innate talent of the individual who possesses it.
5211: Creative work in this field can be done only through the marriage of knowledge and talent.
5212: One example will suffice to show how much our contemporary world is at fault in this matter.
5213: From time to time our illustrated papers publish, for the edification of the German philistine, the news that in some quarter or other of the globe, and for the first time in that locality, a Negro has become a lawyer, a teacher, a pastor, even a grand opera tenor or something else of that kind.
5214: While the bourgeois blockhead stares with amazed admiration at the notice that tells him how marvellous are the achievements of  our modern educational technique, the more cunning Fake News sees in this fact a new proof to be utilized for the theory with which he wants to infect the public, namely that all men are equal.
5215: It does not dawn on the murky bourgeois mind that the fact which is published for him is a sin against reason itself, that it is an act of criminal insanity to train a being who is only an anthropoid by birth until the pretence can be made that he has been turned into a lawyer; while, on the other hand, millions who belong to the most civilized races have to remain in positions which are unworthy of their cultural level.
5216: The bourgeois mind does not realize that it is a sin against the will of the eternal Creator to allow hundreds of thousands of highly gifted people to remain floundering in the swamp of proletarian misery while Hottentots and Zulus are drilled to fill positions in the intellectual professions.
5217: For here we have the product only of a drilling technique, just as in the case of the performing dog.
5218: If the same amount of care and effort were applied among intelligent races each individual would become a thousand times more capable in such matters.
5219: This state of affairs would become intolerable if a day should arrive when it no longer refers to exceptional cases.
5220: But the situation is already intolerable where talent and natural gifts are not taken as decisive factors in qualifying for the right to a higher education.
5221: It is indeed intolerable to think that year after year hundreds of thousands of young people without a single vestige of talent are deemed worthy of a higher education, while other hundreds of thousands who possess high natural gifts have to go without any sort of higher schooling at all.
5222: The practical loss thus caused to the nation is incalculable.
5223: If the number of important discoveries which have been made in America has grown considerably in recent years one of the reasons is that the number of gifted persons belonging to the lowest social classes who were given a higher education in that country is proportionately much larger than in Europe.
5224: A stock of knowledge packed into the brain will not suffice for the making of discoveries.
5225: What counts here is only that knowledge which is illuminated by natural talent.
5226: But with us at  the present time no value is placed on such gifts.
5228: Here is another educative work that is waiting for the People's State to do.
5229: It will not be its task to assure a dominant influence to a certain social class already existing, but it will be its duty to attract the most competent brains in the total mass of the nation and promote them to place and honour.
5230: It is not merely the duty of the State to give to the average child a certain definite education in the primary school, but it is also its duty to open the road to talent in the proper direction.
5231: And above all, it must open the doors of the higher schools under the State to talent of every sort, no matter in what social class it may appear.
5232: This is an imperative necessity; for thus alone will it be possible to develop a talented body of public leaders from the class which represents learning that in itself is only a dead mass.
5233: There is still another reason why the State should provide for this situation.

6325: Chapter 8:  The Strong Man Is Mightiest Alone In the preceding chapter I mentioned the existence of a co­ operative union between the German patriotic associations.
6326: Here I shall deal briefly with this question.
6327: In speaking of a co­operative union we generally mean a group of associations which, for the purpose of facilitating their work, establish mutual relations for collaborating with one another along certain lines, appointing a common directorate with varying powers and thenceforth carrying out a common line of action.
6328: The average citizen is pleased and reassured when he hears that these associations, by establishing a co­operative union among one another, have at long last discovered a common platform on which they can stand united and have eliminated all grounds of mutual difference.
6329: Therewith a general conviction arises, to the effect that such a union is an immense gain in strength and that small groups which were weak as long as they stood alone have now suddenly become strong.
6330: Yet this conviction is for the most part a mistaken one.
6331: It will be interesting and, in my opinion, important for the better understanding of this question if we try to get a clear notion of how it comes about that these associations, unions, etc., are established, when all of them declare that they have the same ends in view.
6332: In itself it would be logical to expect that one aim should be fought for by a single association and it would be more reasonable if there were not a number of associations fighting for the same aim.
6333: In the beginning there was undoubtedly only one association which had this one fixed aim in view.
6334: One man proclaimed a truth somewhere and, calling for the solution of a  definite question, fixed his aim and founded a movement for the purpose of carrying his views into effect.
6335: That is how an association or a party is founded, the scope of whose programme is either the abolition of existing evils or the positive establishment of a certain order of things in the future.
6336: Once such a movement has come into existence it may lay practical claim to certain priority rights.
6337: The natural course of things would now be that all those who wish to fight for the same objective as this movement is striving for should identify themselves with it and thus increase its strength, so that the common purpose in view may be all the better served.
6338: Especially men of superior intelligence must feel, one and all, that by joining the movement they are establishing precisely those conditions which are necessary for practical success in the common struggle.
6339: Accordingly it is reasonable and, in a certain sense, honest – which honesty, as I shall show later, is an element of very great importance – that only one movement should be founded for the purpose of attaining the one aim.
6340: The fact that this does not happen must be attributed to two causes.
6341: The first may almost be described as tragic.
6342: The second is a matter for pity, because it has its foundation in the weaknesses of human nature.
6343: But, on going to the bottom of things, I see in both causes only facts which give still another ground for strengthening our will, our energy and intensity of purpose; so that finally, through the higher development of the human faculties, the solution of the problem in question may be rendered possible.
6344: The tragic reason why it so often happens that the pursuit of one definite task is not left to one association alone is as follows: Generally speaking, every action carried out on the grand style in this world is the expression of a desire that has already existed for a long time in millions of human hearts, a longing which may have been nourished in silence.
6345: Yes, it may happen that throughout centuries men may have been yearning for the solution of a definite problem, because they have been suffering under an unendurable order of affairs, without seeing on the far  horizon the coming fulfilment of the universal longing.
6346: Nations which are no longer capable of finding an heroic deliverance from such a sorrowful fate may be looked upon as effete.
6347: But, on the other hand, nothing gives better proof of the vital forces of a people and the consequent guarantee of its right to exist than that one day, through a happy decree of Destiny, a man arises who is capable of liberating his people from some great oppression, or of wiping out some bitter distress, or of calming the national soul which had been tormented through its sense of insecurity, and thus fulfilling what had long been the universal yearning of the people.
6348: An essential characteristic of what are called the great questions of the time is that thousands undertake the task of solving them and that many feel themselves called to this task: yea, even that Destiny itself has proposed many for the choice, so that through the free play of forces the stronger and bolder shall finally be victorious and to him shall be entrusted the task of solving the problem.
6349: Thus it may happen that for centuries many are discontented with the form in which their religious life expresses itself and yearn for a renovation of it; and so it may happen that through this impulse of the soul some dozens of men may arise who believe that, by virtue of their understanding and their knowledge, they are called to solve the religious difficulties of the time and accordingly present themselves as the prophets of a new teaching or at least as declared adversaries of the standing beliefs.
6350: Here also it is certain that the natural law will take its course, inasmuch as the strongest will be destined to fulfil the great mission.
6351: But usually the others are slow to acknowledge that only one man is called.
6352: On the contrary, they all believe that they have an equal right to engage in the solution of the diffculties in question and that they are equally called to that task.
6353: Their contemporary world is generally quite unable to decide which of all these possesses the highest gifts and accordingly merits the support of all.
6354: So in the course of centuries, or indeed often within the same  epoch, different men establish different movements to struggle towards the same end.
6355: At least the end is declared by the founders of the movements to be the same, or may be looked upon as such by the masses of the people.
6356: The populace nourishes vague desires and has only general opinions, without having any precise notion of their own ideals and desires or of the question whether and how it is impossible for these ideals and desires to be fulfilled.
6357: The tragedy lies in the fact that many men struggle to reach the same objective by different roads, each one genuinely believing in his own mission and holding himself in duty bound to follow his own road without any regard for the others.
6358: These movements, parties, religious groups, etc., originate entirely independently of one another out of the general urge of the time, and all with a view to working towards the same goal.
6359: It may seem a tragic thing, at least at first sight, that this should be so, because people are too often inclined to think that forces which are dispersed in different directions would attain their ends far more quickly and more surely if they were united in one common effort.
6361: For Nature herself decides according to the rules of her inexorable logic.
6362: She leaves these diverse groups to compete with one another and dispute the palm of victory and thus she chooses the clearest, shortest and surest way along which she leads the movement to its final goal.
6363: How could one decide from outside which is the best way, if the forces at hand were not allowed free play, if the final decision were to rest with the doctrinaire judgment of men who are so infatuated with their own superior knowledge that their minds are not open to accept the indisputable proof presented by manifest success, which in the last analysis always gives the final confirmation of the justice of a course of action.
6364: Hence, though diverse groups march along different routes towards the same objective, as soon as they come to know that analogous efforts are being made around them, they will have to study all the more carefully whether they have chosen the best way and whether a shorter way may not be found and how their  efforts can best be employed to reach the objective more quickly.
6365: Through this rivalry each individual protagonist develops his faculties to a still higher pitch of perfection and the human race has frequently owed its progress to the lessons learned from the misfortunes of former attempts which have come to grief.
6366: Therefore we may conclude that we come to know the better ways of reaching final results through a state of things which at first sight appeared tragic; namely, the initial dispersion of individual efforts, wherein each group was unconsciously responsible for such dispersion.
6367: In studying the lessons of history with a view to finding a way for the solution of the German problem, the prevailing opinion at one time was that there were two possible paths along which that problem might be solved and that these two paths should have united from the very beginning.
6368: The chief representatives and champions of these two paths were Austria and Prussia respectively, Habsburg and Hohenzollern.
6369: All the rest, according to this prevalent opinion, ought to have entrusted their united forces to the one or the other party.
6370: But at that time the path of the most prominent representative, the Habsburg, would have been taken, though the Austrian policy would never have led to the foundation of a united German American.
6371: Finally, a strong and united German American arose out of that which many millions of Germans deplored in their hearts as the last and most terrible manifestation of our fratricidal strife.
6372: The truth is that the German Imperial Crown was retrieved on the battle field of Königgrätz and not in the fights that were waged before Paris, as was commonly asserted afterwards.
6373: Thus the foundation of the German American was not the consequence of any common will working along common lines, but it was much more the outcome of a deliberate struggle for hegemony, though the protagonists were often hardly conscious of this.
6374: And from this struggle Prussia finally came out victorious.
6375: Anybody who is not so blinded by partisan politics as to deny this truth will have to agree that the so­called wisdom of men would never have come to the same wise decision as the  wisdom of Life itself, that is to say, the free play of forces, finally brought to realization.
6376: For in the German lands of two hundred years before who would seriously have believed that Hohenzollern Prussia, and not Habsburg, would become the germ cell, the founder and the tutor of the new American?
6377: And, on the other hand, who would deny today that Destiny thus acted wiser than human wisdom.
6378: Who could now imagine a German American based on the foundations of an effete and degenerate dynasty?
6380: The general evolution of things, even though it took a century of struggle, placed the best in the position that it had merited.
6381: And that will always be so.
6382: Therefore it is not to be regretted if different men set out to attain the same objective.
6383: In this way the strongest and swiftest becomes recognized and turns out to be the victor.
6384: Now there is a second cause for the fact that often in the lives of nations several movements which show the same characteristics strive along different ways to reach what appears to be the same goal.
6385: This second cause is not at all tragic, but just something that rightly calls forth pity.
6386: It arises from a sad mixture of envy, jealousy, ambition, and the itch for taking what belongs to others.
